markups: ''The performance of actions or utterances of one's character.''

Players in games are often given characters to control and can through these perform actions in the game. <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> occurs when players are actually performing the actions that their characters are doing.

<style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> is one of the sought after player activities in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fiasco">Fiasco</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Paranoia">Paranoia</link></style>. It occurs less frequently in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Massively%20Multiplayer%20Online%20Games">Massively Multiplayer Online Games</link></style> but some servers for games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> are dedicated to roleplaying and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Massively%20Multiplayer%20Online%20Games">MUDs</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/DragonMud">DragonMud</link></style> focus upon it.

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Guitar%20Hero%20series">Guitar Hero</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Rock%20Band%20series">Rock Band series</link></style> let players enact playing musical instruments.

While a player that pressed the jump button in a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario</link></style> game can make Mario jump, that player is activating and not performing a jump.

Unless using <style="Link"><link="mimetic-interfaces">Mimetic Interfaces</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> requires the presence of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> - either those controlled by players or by <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> - and players may be inspired to perform <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> simply because these <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> exist or because they are engaging in <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>. However, <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> is not something required in most games with <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, with the exception of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Live%20Action%20Roleplaying%20Games">Live Action Roleplaying Games</link></style>. It is something typically strived for by players and game masters in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="warming-up-roleplay-exercises">Warming-Up Roleplay Exercises</link></style> are various activities developed for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Live%20Action%20Roleplaying%20Games">Live Action Roleplaying Games</link></style> that help players prepare and train for <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> can be done by small means. In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style>, players can say what their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> say and look, point, etc. at the other players to indicate that their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> are doing these actions. <style="Link"><link="physical-enactment">Physical Enactment</link></style> is the <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> of actions that require larger movement or more demanding skills (one common difference is that non-physical <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> does not require <style="Link"><link="dexterity-based-actions">Dexterity-Based Actions</link></style>), and when combined with <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> this gives rise to <style="Link"><link="live-action-roleplaying">Live Action Roleplaying</link></style>.

A weak form of <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> is when players describe what their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> do. This is often interwoven with the previous form of <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> but in games with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Illocutionary%20Interfaces">Illocutionary Interfaces</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="mediated-gameplay">Mediated Gameplay</link></style> this may be the only way actions are presented, i.e. <style="Link"><link="chat-channels">Chat Channels</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style> are the media through which these actions are presented. <style="Link"><link="emotes">Emotes</link></style> can be an important tool in these situations and blurs the lines of what is <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> since some of these activate animated sequences for <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="contextualization">Contextualization</link></style> is an option for games with <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> so that <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> can be inserted where players can enact backstories or glimpses of futures. <style="Link"><link="prompting-techniques">Prompting Techniques</link></style> can be used in <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> to help players negotiate or signal changes in <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> but is primarily used in games with <style="Link"><link="physical-enactment">Physical Enactment</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> can be created from having players enact their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> actions. However, there is a risk of breaking <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> whenever players have the chance of including non-diegetic concepts into <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style>.

The combination of <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> and <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> typically gives rise to <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style>. As gameplay based on <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> provides performances by players, the use of it motivates the presence of ways to make recordings of these, i.e. <style="Link"><link="replays">Replays</link></style>, to view or present later; this is however most likely the case if the <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> is actually <style="Link"><link="physical-enactment">Physical Enactment</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> allows actions to be slightly different from each other, and since this can depend on the surroundings in which the actions are performed, the pattern allows for <style="Link"><link="performance-uncertainty">Performance Uncertainty</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="context-dependent-reactions">Context Dependent Reactions</link></style>. Successfully performing the required actions can provide players with a sense of <style="Link"><link="role-fulfillment">Role Fulfillment</link></style>. While not all <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> requires <style="Link"><link="social-skills">Social Skills</link></style>, those that include interacting with other people typically do.

All effects of <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> which does not affect the game state is <style="Link"><link="extra-game-consequences">Extra-Game Consequences</link></style> that in many cases also can provide <style="Link"><link="social-rewards">Social Rewards</link></style> as others can appreciate the performances. However, <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> can give rise to <style="Link"><link="player-character-skill-composites">Player/Character Skill Composites</link></style> when the <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> of players can affect other players' behavior or the opinion of <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>. That said, players may identify more with their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> by having performed their actions themselves, and through this gain an <style="Link"><link="emotional-attachment">Emotional Attachment</link></style> to them.

<style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> is often a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style>, especially when two or more players are engaged in it at the same time. This can lead to players <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competing%20for%20Attention">Competing for Attention</link></style>, especially in games with <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>. Further, <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> is a skill and becoming good at it is a form of <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style>. The two points, and the fact that <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> draws attention argues why <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> support the "exhibitionist" <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Role</link></style>.

As has been mentioned above, <style="CurrentLink">Enactment</style> risks breaking <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> and is likely to produce <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style> when used together with <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>.
